questions.text: What is a Database Management System (DBMS), and how does it differ from a traditional file system?
options: DBMS is a software for managing databases, whereas a file system handles individual files separately.
DBMS is a type of file system that organizes files in a structured manner.
File systems are more efficient than DBMS for handling large amounts of data.
DBMS does not provide data security, while file systems do.
questions.correctAnswer: DBMS is a software for managing databases, whereas a file system handles individual files separately.

questions.text: What are the key advantages of a DBMS over a file system?
options: DBMS provides better data integrity, security, and eliminates redundancy compared to file systems.
File systems allow multiple users to access data simultaneously, whereas DBMS does not.
DBMS does not support data consistency, whereas file systems do.
DBMS is more complex than file systems, making it less efficient.
questions.correctAnswer: DBMS provides better data integrity, security, and eliminates redundancy compared to file systems.

questions.text: What are the main components of a DBMS?
options: Hardware, Software, Data, Users, Database Schema
Hardware, File System, Compiler, Queries
Software, Data, RAM, CPU
Tables, Functions, Algorithms, Users
questions.correctAnswer: Hardware, Software, Data, Users, Database Schema

questions.text: What is Data Abstraction in DBMS?
options: Hiding the complex internal details of how data is stored and maintained, allowing users to interact with a simplified model.
Showing all data to the user without any restrictions.
A process that stores all data in raw format without processing.
A feature of file systems, not DBMS.
questions.correctAnswer: Hiding the complex internal details of how data is stored and maintained, allowing users to interact with a simplified model.

questions.text: What are the three levels of Data Abstraction in DBMS?
options: Physical Level, Logical Level, View Level
File Level, Schema Level, User Level
Primary Level, Secondary Level, Tertiary Level
Storage Level, Query Level, Index Level
questions.correctAnswer: Physical Level, Logical Level, View Level

questions.text: What is Physical Level Data Abstraction?
options: It describes how data is stored in the database, including file storage structures and indexing.
It defines how users interact with data without worrying about storage details.
It only shows a limited amount of data to authorized users.
It is used only in file systems and not in DBMS.
questions.correctAnswer: It describes how data is stored in the database, including file storage structures and indexing.

questions.text: What is Logical Level Data Abstraction?
options: It defines the structure of the entire database, including relationships, constraints, and tables.
It deals with the physical storage of data on the hard disk.
It provides security by restricting data access to certain users.
It defines how data is presented to the end users.
questions.correctAnswer: It defines the structure of the entire database, including relationships, constraints, and tables.

questions.text: What is View Level Data Abstraction?
options: It provides a customized representation of the database for different users.
It defines how data is stored physically.
It describes how data is structured logically.
It is used only in file systems, not DBMS.
questions.correctAnswer: It provides a customized representation of the database for different users.

questions.text: What is Data Independence in DBMS?
options: The ability to modify the database schema at one level without affecting the schema at the next higher level.
A feature that allows users to access all the data without restrictions.
A property of file systems that improves performance.
The ability to retrieve data without using queries.
questions.correctAnswer: The ability to modify the database schema at one level without affecting the schema at the next higher level.

questions.text: What are the two types of Data Independence?
options: Logical Data Independence and Physical Data Independence
File Data Independence and Query Data Independence
User Data Independence and Server Data Independence
Primary Data Independence and Secondary Data Independence
questions.correctAnswer: Logical Data Independence and Physical Data Independence

options: The ability to change the logical structure of the database without affecting applications that use it.
The ability to change the physical storage structure without affecting the logical schema.
A method used to store data in file systems.
The ability to change the data format without affecting performance.
questions.correctAnswer: The ability to change the logical structure of the database without affecting applications that use it.

options: The ability to modify the physical storage of data without affecting the logical structure.
The ability to modify database queries without affecting data retrieval.
A technique used only in file systems.
A feature that allows multiple users to access data simultaneously.
questions.correctAnswer: The ability to modify the physical storage of data without affecting the logical structure.

questions.text: What are the three levels of DBMS architecture?
options: Internal Level, Conceptual Level, External Level
File Level, Query Level, Index Level
Application Level, Database Level, Server Level
Primary Level, Secondary Level, Tertiary Level
questions.correctAnswer: Internal Level, Conceptual Level, External Level

questions.text: What is the role of the Internal Level in DBMS architecture?
options: It defines how data is physically stored on storage devices.
It represents the logical structure of the entire database.
It provides different views for different users.
It deals with query processing only.
questions.correctAnswer: It defines how data is physically stored on storage devices.

questions.text: What is the function of the External Level in DBMS architecture?
options: It provides individual users with different views of the database as per their needs.
It handles data storage and indexing.
It defines how tables are structured at a physical level.
It ensures that only admins can access the database.
questions.correctAnswer: It provides individual users with different views of the database as per their needs.
